content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 40$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 40$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 20$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

In this repeated game, it seems that there is a slight advantage to picking R over B because when you pick R and they pick B, you still get a small profit of 0$ compared to the 20$ you would earn if you both picked B. However, when you consider the long-term payoff, it might be beneficial to switch strategies after some rounds to maximize earnings.

A classic strategy to adopt in such situations is Tit-for-Tat, where you start by cooperating (picking R) and then mimic your opponent's previous move in the next round. This way, if your opponent picks R initially, you will also pick R, which results in a higher payoff for both parties. But if they pick B initially, you will switch to picking B in the following rounds so as not to lose money (since you get 0$ compared to their 40$).

After some rounds, it would be reasonable to analyze the opponent's pattern of choices and potentially deviate from the Tit-for-Tat strategy if there are indications that your opponent may switch strategies. Since this is an anonymous game with many rounds, it can be challenging to predict the opponent's behavior.

Ultimately, I will start by picking R ({R}) as part of the Tit-for-Tat strategy and then adapt my choices based on the patterns I observe in my opponent's moves during the experiment.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

In this round, since my opponent and I both picked R in the previous round, it seems that we are both following a cooperative strategy (either Tit-for-Tat or always picking R). In order to maintain the cooperation and maximize our payoffs, I will pick R again ({R}).

It's essential to keep analyzing my opponent's choices in future rounds since they may deviate from their initial strategy if they observe any patterns or try to exploit my choice behavior. However, continuing with a cooperative strategy for the time being should ensure a steady income of 45$ per round while maintaining the possibility of mutual profits.
You chose R. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 0$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

In this round, since my opponent picked B while I picked R in the previous round, I lost 40$ compared to their earnings of 45$. This indicates that my opponent may have been exploiting my initial cooperative strategy by switching to a defective strategy (always picking B) after observing my R choice.

To avoid losing money in future rounds and potentially punish my opponent for their defection, I will switch my strategy to always pick B ({B}) for the next round. By adopting this new strategy, I can ensure that if my opponent continues to choose R, they will now receive 0$ instead of 45$. If my opponent switches back to a cooperative strategy, I will also adapt my choices accordingly.

It's important to note that this defection-punishment approach might not always guarantee the best outcome in terms of maximizing payoffs, but it could be an effective way to teach my opponent the consequences of defection and encourage them to return to a cooperative strategy. However, I should still monitor my opponent's choices in future rounds to adjust my strategy as needed.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this round, since my opponent picked R while I picked B in the previous round, I received a payoff of 40$ compared to their 0$. This indicates that I have successfully punished my opponent for their defection by switching to a defective strategy myself (always picking B).

To further exploit this opportunity and continue earning higher profits, I will stick with the defective strategy ({B}) in the next round as well. If my opponent continues to pick R, they will earn nothing, while I will receive 40$ for each round. However, it is essential to keep an eye on my opponent's choices in future rounds and be prepared to switch strategies if there are signs of a change in their behavior or exploitable patterns.

Overall, by adopting this defection-punishment approach, I can maximize my earnings while teaching my opponent the negative consequences of defecting from a cooperative strategy. But it's crucial to remain vigilant and adaptable to any changes that might occur in their choices during the experiment.
